SubTopics: Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 ÷ 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each.
Content: A teacher arranged 42 bottle caps into 7 rows with the same number of bottle caps in each row.
Which expression can be used to find the number of bottle caps the teacher put in each row?

SubTopics: Represent a fraction 1/b on a number line diagram by defining the interval from 0 to 1 as the whole and partitioning it into b equal parts. Recognize that each part has size 1/b and that the endpoint of the part based at 0 locates the number 1/b on the number line.
Content: What fraction is represented by the point on the number line?
problems/MDG3M/media/2a.jpg

SubTopics: Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step “how many more” and “how may less” problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs.
Content: The following bar graph shows the number of cars of each color that passed by a school during a certain period of time.
problems/MDG3M/media/3a.jpg
How many more silver cars passed by the school than black cars and white cars combined?

SubTopics: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.
Content: Complete the following equation.

SubTopics: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
Content: Which shape is partitioned into fourths?

SubTopics: Understand a fraction 1/bb as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.
Content: A student divided a sheet of paper into sections of equal size.
The student drew flowers on some of the sections as shown.
problems/MDG3M/media/6a.jpg
On what fraction of the sections of paper did the student draw flowers?

SubTopics: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations.
Content: What is the result when an even number is multiplied by 5 ?

A.Choice: The result is an even number with a 0 in the ones place.

B.Choice: The result is an odd number with a 0 in the ones place.

C.Choice: The result is an even number with a 5 in the ones place.

D.Choice: The result is an odd number with a 5 in the ones place.

SubTopics: Represent two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the same size, or the same point on the number line.
Content: Which TWO number lines show points that represent equivalent fractions?

SubTopics: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
Content: The following figure shows the rectangular floor of Mr. Soto's garage. Mr. Soto will paint the entire floor.
problems/MDG3M/media/9a.jpg
Which equation represents the amount of space that Mr. Soto will paint?

SubTopics: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Content: What is the value of the following expression?

SubTopics: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.
Content: An expression is shown.
:ibox:3 × 10
Which TWO expressions have the same value as the given expression?

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Content: Which comparison is true?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
Content: A student wants to put a border around a notebook that measures 8 inches wide and 10 inches long.
The student thinks that the perimeter of the notebook is 18 inches because 8 + 10 = 18.
Which sentence explains how to correct the student's thinking?

A.Choice: The student should have multiplied 8 by 10, then multiplied 10 by 8, and then added the two products.

B.Choice: The student should have multiplied 8 by 10, then multiplied 10 by 2, and then added the two products.

C.Choice: The student should have multiplied 8 by 2, then multiplied 10 by 2, and then added the two products.

D.Choice: The student should have multiplied 8 by 2, then multiplied 10 by 8, and then added the two products.

SubTopics: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Content: Wylie Elementary School has students in 1 st through 6th grade.
The table shows the number of present and absent students for different grades on a certain day.
problems/MDG3M/media/14a.jpg
Which TWO questions could be answered based on the information in the table?

A.Choice: What is the total number of students in the school?

B.Choice: What is the total number of students who are in the 1st grade?

C.Choice: What is the total number of students who are in the 4th grade?

D.Choice: What is the total number of absent students on that day in the 2nd grade and the 3rd grade?

E.Choice: What is the total number of present students on that day in the 5th grade and the 6th grade?

SubTopics: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, or arrays, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Content: A teacher is making supply boxes for her students to use when they work in groups.

:ibox:• There are 9 supply boxes.

• Each supply box will have 6 colored markers.

• The teacher has 15 colored markers to put in the supply boxes.
The teacher thinks that 39 more markers are needed to fill the supply boxes because 6 × 9 = 54 and 54 – 15 = 39.
Explain why the teacher's thinking is correct by explaining what the two equations represent in the problem.

SubTopics: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
Content: A gardener has a rectangular garden.

:ibox:• The length of the garden is 6 feet.

• The width of the garden is 3 feet.
Which expression could be used to find the area, in square feet, of the garden?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
Content: A pet store owner built two rectangular dog pens next to each other.
The picture shows the floors of the two dog pens.
problems/MDG3M/media/17a.jpg
The pet store owner will cover the floors of the dog pens with concrete.
What is the total area, in square feet, of the floors of the two dog pens?

SubTopics: Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers.
Content: Which TWO equations are true based on the values represented by the point on the number line?

SubTopics: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, or arrays, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Content: Diana had 63 feet of rope. She cut the rope into 7 pieces of equal length.
Which expression represents the length, in feet, of each piece of rope?

SubTopics: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions, e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3. Explain why the fractions are equivalent, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Content: In which three figures does the shaded part represent 1/2 of the figure?

SubTopics: Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real-world problems.
Content: The figure shows a garden.
The figure is composed of two rectangles that do not overlap.
problems/MDG3M/media/21a.jpg
What is the area, in square feet, of the garden?

SubTopics: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
Content: Which shape is a quadrilateral?

SubTopics: Represent a fraction a/b on a number line diagram by marking off a lengths of 1/bfrom 0. Recognize that the resulting interval has size a/b and that its endpoint locates the number a/b on the number line.
Content: Point W represents a fraction on the number line.
problems/MDG3M/media/23a.jpg
Which fraction is represented by point W ?

SubTopics: Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms kg), and liters (l). Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as a beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem.
Content: Terry bought 2 bags of beans. The mass of each bag, in grams, is shown on the scales.
problems/MDG3M/media/24a.jpg
How many grams of beans did Terry buy in all?

SubTopics: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.
Content: Round 148 to the nearest 10.

SubTopics: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit n
Content: Which TWO equations could be used to find the result of 7 × 5?

SubTopics: Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers.
Content: Byron will write a fraction that is equivalent to 1. The denominator is 2.
What number will Byron use in the numerator to write the fraction?

SubTopics: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 × 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.
Content: The picture shows marbles in jars.
problems/MDG3M/media/28a.jpg
Which expression could be used to find the total number of marbles in the jars?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
Content: A window is in the shape of a rectangle. The perimeter of the window is 24 feet.
Which TWO pairs of measurements could be the length and width of the window?

A.Choice: Length is 4 feet and width is 6 feet

B.Choice: Length is 7 feet and width is 5 feet

C.Choice: Length is 8 feet and width is 3 feet

D.Choice: Length is 9 feet and width is 3 feet

E.Choice: Length is 12 feet and width is 12 feet

F.Choice: Length is 14 feet and width is 10 feet

SubTopics: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, or arrays, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Content: A gym teacher took some bags of soccer balls to the soccer field.
The teacher put 6 soccer balls in each bag.
What other information is needed to find how many bags of soccer balls the teacher took to the field?

A.Choice: the total number of students in the gym class

B.Choice: the total number of players on the school's soccer team

C.Choice: the total number of soccer balls the teacher took to the field

D.Choice: the total number of soccer balls each group of students will get

SubTopics: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, or arrays, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Content: A student made 20 necklaces.

:ibox:• The student put 5 beads on each necklace.

• There were 10 beads in each package.
Which statement explains the student's correct thinking to find the total number of beads the student used to make all the necklaces?

A.Choice: The student thinks that there are 20 necklaces and there are 10 beads in each package, and 20 ÷ 10 = 2.

B.Choice: The student thinks that there are 20 necklaces and there are 10 beads in each package, and 20 × 10 = 200.

C.Choice: The student thinks that there are 20 necklaces and there are 5 beads on each necklace, and 20 ÷ 5 = 4.

D.Choice: The student thinks that there are 20 necklaces and there are 5 beads on each necklace, and 20 × 5 = 100.

SubTopics: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
Content: Rafael will cover a rectangular board with square labels. He will buy packages of square labels. Each package contains 6 labels of the same size.
The following figure shows the side lengths of the board and of one label.
problems/MDG3M/media/32a.jpg
What is the least number of labels Rafael needs to cover the board? Show your work or explain how you found your answer.
What is the least number of packages of labels Rafael should buy? Show your work or explain how you found your answer.

SubTopics: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 × 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.
Content: A farmer has a field with 4 rows of apple trees. There are 9 trees in each row.
Which expression could be used to find the total number of apple trees the farmer has in the field?

SubTopics: Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 ÷ 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each.
Content: A student has several pennies.
The student organized the pennies into the array shown.
problems/MDG3M/media/34a.jpg
The student wants to put all the pennies in stacks with the same number of pennies in each stack.
Explain three different ways the student could put the pennies in stacks with the same number of pennies in each stack.
Explain how you used the array of pennies to help you find the different ways to stack the pennies.

SubTopics: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.
Content: A student wrote the expression 7 + 7 + 7 + 7 + 7 to find the value of 7 × 5.
The student said that when writing a different expression to represent 7 × 5, only the numbers 7 and 5 can be used.
Which TWO expressions could be used to show that the student's response is incorrect?
